text: usually I go out an assignment carrying
a notebook but recently I left our
newsroom in Times Square carrying a
borrowed kayak and headed to the west
side of Manhattan for a little journey
to explore the Hudson River I'm Corey
Kilgannon with the new york times in
1609 Henry Hudson made his now-famous
exploration of the river we now called
the Hudson I'm going to try to replicate
henry hudsons voyage under starting this
kayak I'm going to head north and trying
to hitchhike rides with as many
different vessels I can find up the
river now I'm not a kayaker and I had
certainly never paddled in the Hudson
before but I'll tell you it was a lot of
fun very exciting I was cruising uptown
with the incoming tide I barely had to
paddle now I live on the west side of
Manhattan but I never really looked at
it from the water there was a lot of
flotsam and jetsam along the coast but
the water was pretty clean in the middle
where I ran into the heath family whose
two children was swimming off the boat
hey what do you think of my idea I want
to go all the way up the hudson river to
albany sounds awesome awesome do you
think it's foolish a hot dog vendor in
Riverside Park refused to take my money
and threw me a hotdog much needed fuel
for my journey later on off the coast of
Harlem it hooked up with a half moon a
replica of the ship Henry Hudson used
this historic three-masted vessel was
heading upriver and agreed to let me
aboard the crew lashed my kayak to the
deck and went back to climbing the
rigging and furling and unfurling the
sales that's captainship Reynolds who
sails his ship the Henry Hudson way he
wanted all the rigging in the ropes
shipshape and he had his crew swabbing
the deck the Sun was setting and we
passed under the Tappan Zee Bridge and
dropped anchor next to hook mountain
near nayak not far from where Hudson
also
anchor on day two we had breakfast on
deck and a local guy named Chris Vargo
who grew up fishing and hunting on the
Hudson was good enough to pick me up it
was goodbye to the half moon and on up
the river here the water is crystal
clear I'm coming in for night across the
river it's the time cleaner now than it
was when I was a kid and it's probably
it was cleaning when I was a kid than
with my father was a kid
at a marina in newburgh Lex Philip ow
ski a motivational speaker with a
15-foot jet boat was happy to give a
ride to me and Chris Fargo's father John
Fargo right now we're at the Newport
waterfront it replaced the e the place
to be people with great nightlife we
knocked around the area of beacon and
cold spring and I was really just blown
away by the dramatic highlands that
surrounded the river it felt like a big
mountain lake a real change from the
urban Hudson I was used to we saw an
island up the head with an old crumbling
castle on it Bannerman's Island where an
arms dealer named Francis Bannerman once
lived in warehoused his munitions the
steward of the island Dave Lawrence gave
me a special tour inside the structures
this is the entrance to the Arsenal here
on Bannerman which is believed for
stories and a flat roof in this level is
where they stored the cannons he had
cannons from the Civil War here
it struck me how much of a boaters
paradise the river was up here full of
kayakers and tour boats water skiers we
pulled up on little Stony Point Beach
where I met three guys who had watched
the river rebound from it's polluted
path I come here like every weekend
those over the last 40 years just to
come down and relax and enjoy the view
in the scenery in the clean water he's
been calling the water 20 years ago what
was it like this war sewage all over the
place I was probably 40 years ago human
thank you time marches on Zeck we ran
into a guy named Walter gur shaggin who
runs the local sea tow boat monitoring
radio rescue channels and helping out
voters in trouble this fella thinks he's
out of gas he's just floating in front
of West Point went down here past some
random his arsenal yeah the new Barbie
can bridge did we turn her ass all right
let's go back with some gas from Walter
they were on their way it was the end of
my second day and I worried that my
supply of boat rides had dried up but
the next morning we hit the jackpot
the jackpot was a 50-foot 3-bedroom
3-bathroom yacht with a living room
spiral staircase and all the amenities
you can want the owner and captain was a
retired corporate executive named Steve
Martin he even let me drive and I'll
tell you those diesels packed some power
a far cry from my kayak I got dizzy from
the control panel with its sonar and
radar depth finders and every other
navigational tool you could want Captain
Steve took the wheel up on the high deck
and we saw a river that was much more
narrow and pristine plenty of
interesting little villages boat club's
they were aging neglected structures and
little tucked-away beaches this is the
beauty of the Hudson its personality
changes dramatically every few miles at
a marina in New Baltimore we met a
couple that had come up with a pretty
nifty Hudson River business plan they
built a floating hot dog cart named
after their dog rascal what's most
people reaction when they follow I see
what an awesome idea I can't we do this
how did to do this um one lady said can
you build me one just down the road I
met a guy named Alice Trombley pursuing
his own dream started office that's a
big adventure now it's almost become
like an obsession almost an albatross
Dallas has been working for years to
build a homemade raft that could take
him down the river to New York City a
25-foot paddle wheel houseboat is what I
keep on and it's biodiesel powered the
goal at all times but not to use any
fossil fuels because I guess just a lot
of my friends are more the poet's kind
of people and not really engineering
kind of people this is a mixture of both
though this is a dreamers this is the
dream was probably yeah they're really
it I told Dallas I was just as obsessed
to make it upriver to Albany to find
where Hudson ended his journey we
stopped at scarano boat builders in
Albany where Rick scarano told us we'd
have to keep going if he wanted to find
the spot where Hudson found the river
too shallow and called it quits 400
years ago I imagine it was a little
further north than this
because the river is pretty naturally
deep for a little bit yeah it turns out
that spot was it what is now the federal
dam at Troy just north of downtown
Albany searching for a vantage point we
finally came to a dead end and saw a
faint path down to the river's edge and
there it was the end of the navigable
hudson both for me and 400 years ago for
henry hudson
